supporting.text: French is the official language of France, which is a country in Europe, but not all European countries have French as an official language.

attacks.text: French is the official language of France, which is a country in Europe, but not all European countries have French as an official language.
Many Europeans learn French as a second language, making it widely spoken across the continent.
Even if some Europeans learn French, this does not mean they speak it fluently or use it daily.
French is an official language of the European Union, increasing its prevalence in Europe.
The EU has 24 official languages, and French is just one of them, not universally spoken.

supporting.text: Many European countries, such as Germany, Italy, and Spain, have their own distinct official languages that are not French.

attacks.text: Many European countries, such as Germany, Italy, and Spain, have their own distinct official languages that are not French.
Some European countries, like Belgium and Switzerland, have French as one of their official languages.
Even in Belgium and Switzerland, not all regions or citizens speak French fluently or as their primary language.
French is widely taught as a second language in many European schools, increasing its prevalence.
Being taught as a second language does not equate to fluency or everyday usage by the majority of the population.

supporting.text: The European Union recognizes 24 official languages, demonstrating the linguistic diversity of Europe beyond French.

attacks.text: The European Union recognizes 24 official languages, demonstrating the linguistic diversity of Europe beyond French.
French is widely spoken in Europe, particularly in France, Belgium, and Switzerland, making it a dominant language in certain regions.
While French is spoken in some regions, it is not the primary language in most European countries, such as Germany, Italy, or Spain.
French is one of the official languages of the EU and is used in many international institutions, giving it a prominent status in Europe.

supporting.text: English is widely spoken across Europe as a second language, not French, in many non-Francophone countries.

attacks.text: English is widely spoken across Europe as a second language, not French, in many non-Francophone countries.
French is an official language in multiple European countries, such as France, Belgium, and Switzerland, making it widely spoken.
Even in countries where French is official, many regions primarily speak other languages (e.g., German in parts of Switzerland, Dutch in Belgium).
English is taught as a primary foreign language in most European schools, reinforcing its dominance over French.
French remains a key diplomatic and EU administrative language, maintaining its influence despite English's prevalence.

supporting.text: Historical and cultural differences in Europe have led to the development and preservation of numerous languages other than French.

attacks.text: Historical and cultural differences in Europe have led to the development and preservation of numerous languages other than French.
French is widely spoken as a second language in many European countries due to its historical influence.
Even if French is a second language, it does not mean all Europeans speak it fluently or use it daily.
In some regions like Wallonia in Belgium and parts of Switzerland, French is the primary language.
These regions are exceptions and do not represent the majority of European countries where French is not the primary language.
